  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Model
    The abstract base class of all kinds of robots, drones, etc.
    Model_3DR
    A model of the 3DR.
    Model_Drone
    This class represents all airborne models.
    Model_GhostAerial
    A model of the Ehang GhostDrone 2.0.
    Model_Ground
    This class represents all ground models that have zero-point turning.
    Model_iRobot
    A model of the iRobot Create.
    Model_Mavic
    A model of the DJI Mavic.
    Model_Minidrone
    This class represents a simple model of the Parrot Minidrone.
    Model_Phantom
    A model of the DJI Phantom.
    ModelRegistry
    ModelRegistry is a static container class whose purpose is to reduce explicit typing of the concrete Model subclasses.

Package edu.illinois.mitra.starl.models Description

Classes specific to each kind of robot. This package contains classes holding all of the information specific to each kind of robot that StarL can interface with and simulate. Most of the work required to integrate a new robot into StarL is done here, without having to modify any external classes.

Model is the base class for all types of robots, and is used widely to represent the "current robot." It provides abstract methods for characteristics that all types of robots share, including a method to return the type of physical interface to be used to control each robot.

Model_Ground is the base class for non-aerial robots that have zero-point turning, i.e. a forward velocity and an angle.

Model_Drone is the base class for aerial robots that have yaw, pitch, roll, and gaz (vertical velocity).

ModelRegistry is a container class with static methods used to register each non- abstract subclass of Model for use in the rest of StarL.

To add a new kind of robot, you must do the following:

  1. Create a new class representing the robot (Model_YourClass), subclassing the appropriate base class.
  2. Implement all abstract methods.
  3. Add a call to register(Model_YourClass.class) in ModelRegistry.
  4. If no existing ModelInterface is compatible with the new Model, implement an interface that is compatible. Not necessary for simulation.
  5. That's it! StarL is flexible enough to be ready to use your class in applications.
